thread.title: Now Ronaldo bags ‘long-term’ Nike deal
thread.title_full: Now Ronaldo bags ‘long-term’ Nike deal

posts.author: AFP
posts.title: Now Ronaldo bags ‘long-term’ Nike deal
posts.text:
AFP | November 9, 2016 "I have a great relationship with this brand, I have great friends here in the company," Ronaldo said in a Nike press release announcing a "new, long-term contract". 
MADRID: A day after signing a bumper fresh contract with Real Madrid, Cristiano Ronaldo has boosted his mind-boggling earnings with a new deal with Nike, the American sports giant said on Tuesday. 
Together the multimillion mega-deals are expected to cement Ronaldo’s status as the world’s highest-paid sportsman, ahead of great Barcelona rival Lionel Messi. 
According to American magazine Forbes, Ronaldo trumped Messi in 2016 with an income of $88 million (80 million euros, £71 million). 
There are no concrete figures, but Ronaldo’s new five-year contract with Real is expected to net the 31-year-old Portuguese forward in the region of a basic salary of 25 million euros a year. 
He could also bag up to 40 million euros a year for the Nike deal, according to Marca. 
Marca and AS, the Spanish sports dailies, said the Nike deal is for life, rather like the one between Nike and basketball legend Michael Jordan. 
“I have a great relationship with this brand, I have great friends here in the company,” Ronaldo said in a Nike press release announcing a “new, long-term contract”. 
“We work as a family too,” he added. 
“This is my brand.” 
Ronaldo on Monday signalled his intention to keep playing for 10 more years after rounding off a “dream year”. 
The three-time World Player of the Year has enjoyed his most successful year at a collective level, scoring the winning penalty as Madrid won the Champions League for an 11th time in May before captaining Portugal to their first major tournament win at Euro 2016.

thread.title: Nike's Latest AeroLoft Sportswear and Sneakerboots Get Highlighted in New Editorial

posts.author: Hypebeast (info@hypebeast.com)
posts.title: Nike's Latest AeroLoft Sportswear and Sneakerboots Get Highlighted in New Editorial
posts.text:
Winter is well on its way and to stay stylish during the colder months, Nike 's latest apparel and footwear will have you covered. Highlighted in the lookbook are the latest collection of sneakerboots, which will deliver winter protection while keeping true to the iconic looks we've come to love. Nike's Tech Fleece and Aeroloft outerwear essentials are also put in the spotlight, adding a sleek urban feel to any look. Check out the pieces above and head over to Nike's online shop to purchase.
Click here to view full gallery at Hypebeast.com

thread.title: Nike KD 9 PE Oregon Veterans Day | SneakerNews.com

posts.author: Zack Schlemmer
posts.title: Nike KD 9 PE Oregon Veterans Day | SneakerNews.com
posts.text:
Tweet 0 shares / likes 
The Oregon basketball squad is ready to honor our nation’s veterans in style this Friday with special uniforms and a brand-new Nike KD 9 PE. We get a full look at both the stylized digital camo “Fighting Ducks” uniform and the black, yellow, and green KD 9 here, which we can see also features a feather print below the clear outsole. You can catch the Oregon Ducks in the Veterans Day uniform this Friday as they face off against Army.

thread.title: Nike KD 9 Dark Obsidian | SneakerNews.com
thread.title_full: Nike KD 9 Dark Obsidian | SneakerNews.com

posts.author: Patrick Johnson
posts.title: Nike KD 9 Dark Obsidian | SneakerNews.com
posts.text:
Tweet 0 shares / likes 
Oh, hey – this Kevin Durant guy is pretty good. Since joining the Golden State Warriors, a basketball team in the Western Conference that won 73 out of 82 regular season games last year, KD has been nothing short of his usual self, which includes averages of 28 ppg and 8 rbg. His Nike KD 9 has been a stellar performance model thanks to a 3/4 length Zoom-cushioned midsole unit, dynamic Flyknit upper for a malleable, ventilated fit, and unique mid-top ankle support that you just slip into. 
The colorways have been releasing en masse since the start of the regular season with the likes of a KD 9 “Oreo” and KD 9 “Christmas” bridging the gap between on-court functionality and aesthetics that would work equally as well in a lifestyle context. This Niek KD 9 Dark Obsidian continues that momentum with the perfect pop of Hyper Turquoise on the visible Zoom midsole while shades of Dark Obsidian and a lighter slate blue gives the upper a 50/50 split. A metallic Swoosh finishes things off with a premium touch to contrast a stark black midsole. 
Check out more photos of this upcoming KD 9 Dark Obsidian release and we’ll keep you in the loop on an official release date right here on Sneaker News.

thread.title: Nike KD 9 Fire and Ice | SneakerNews.com
thread.title_full: Nike KD 9 Fire and Ice | SneakerNews.com

posts.author: Michael Tam
posts.title: Nike KD 9 Fire and Ice | SneakerNews.com
posts.text:
Tweet 0 shares / likes 
When it comes to the greatness of Kevin Durant, his achievements speak for themselves. From being the MVP of the 2014 NBA season to his countless All-NBA Team awards, these accomplishments reflect years of grueling drudgery in his earlier years. As a kid, Durant’s hometown of Baltimore, Maryland encountered harsh weather conditions during the winter but that wouldn’t stop Durant from pursuing his dreams. While practicing his shots out on the courts, his hands would freeze from the frigid temperatures and in an attempt to warm up his hands, he would often pour hot water on them. 
The new Nike KD 9 “Fire and Ice” are inspired by this hardship on the court in his earlier days. The sneakers feature a red left shoe with a fiery graphic and a blue left shoe with an icy toe to represent the “Fire and Ice” concept from Durant’s humble beginnings. The sneakers are available now as a kid’s exclusive at select Nike Basketball retailers such as Solefly . "Air Jordan 11 Premium Grey Suede" "nike kd 9"

Kylie Jenner for Puma , Gigi Hadid for Adidas , and now Bella Hadid for Nike !
We'll never escape them!
Bella is the latest of the It-girl squad to score herself a contract with a major athletic brand, and she certainly has the ripped abs for it!
Photos: Worst Dressed Celebs Of The Week
On Monday, the supermodel posted a pic of herself wearing a crop top and posing near a billboard of herself repping Nike. Nice!
The 20-year-old captioned the photo:
"🏁so excited to announce that I am OFFICIALLY PART OF THE @NIKEFAMILY! More coming very soon"
Jeez, these girls just keep on winning and winning! Don't you wish you'd been born to rich parents, Perezcious readers???
Life ain't fair!

thread.title: The price of Nike’s self-lacing sneakers revealed, and yeah, they’re *definitely* going to cost you
thread.title_full: The price of Nike’s self-lacing sneakers revealed, and yeah, they’re *definitely* going to cost you

posts.author: Kenya Foy
posts.title: The price of Nike’s self-lacing sneakers revealed, and yeah, they’re *definitely* going to cost you
posts.text:
The price of Nike’s self-lacing sneakers revealed, and yeah, they’re *definitely* going to cost you If you ever dreamed of dressing like Marty McFly, the time to sport Back to the Future -inspired fashions is mere weeks away. Since Nike unveiled its tech-meets-fashion HyperAdapt 1.0 earlier in the year, we hope you’ve been saving your coins because the self-lacing sneakers will cost you a pretty penny.
How much is that exactly? Think expensive, but slightly less pricey than the $895 pair of Louboutins that almost wrecked Zendaya’s feet on the red carpet. Fine, we’ll stop teasing now and give it to ya straight: Gizmodo reports that the highly anticipated self-lacing sneakers will go for $720 when they drop on Dec. 1.

Um…wow. So, clearly the price of these kicks will test the loyalty of die-hard Back to the Future fans and shoe lovers who *so* badly want present reality to reflect the coolness of the film’s futuristic dystopia. Like, who knew laziness cost this much?!
Introducing The Nike HyperAdapt 1.0 Lacing up will never be the same. Click the link in our bio to learn more. 
A photo posted by nike (@nike) on Mar 16, 2016 at 9:53pm PDT 
But as the saying goes, beauty is pain and fashion is beauty (or something like that), so we have a feeling that for many folks who want to rock these shoes, the choice between owning a pair or paying a credit card bill and buying groceries for the month just got that much more difficult.
The post The price of Nike’s self-lacing sneakers revealed, and yeah, they’re *definitely* going to cost you appeared first on HelloGiggles .

thread.title: Nike Is Worth A Closer Look
thread.title_full: Nike Is Worth A Closer Look

posts.title: Nike Is Worth A Closer Look
posts.text:
Summary 
Nike has had an excellent business and security history over the years. 
If you were to screen for dividend yields or valuations, Nike probably wouldn’t come up on your list. 
However, due to the inherent quality and potential for growth, the security could now be worth a closer look with a materially lower share price this year. Upon first glance, shares of Nike (NYSE: NKE ) may not appear all that attractive. Depending on where you look, the security is trading hands around 22 or 23 times earnings. With a $0.16 quarterly dividend this equates to a "current" starting yield of about 1.3%. Neither metric is especially compelling, especially for such a well-established firm. And to be sure, Nike likely gets skipped over in many stock screens looking for a minimum yield or lower earnings multiple. Yet I would contend that Nike's inherent quality and remaining potential ought to warrant a closer look. The investing world is fun because not everything trades at (or should trade at) 15 times earnings year-in and year-out. Instead you have to contemplate faster growing companies with loftier valuations as compared to slower growing businesses with more reasonable values. Or a lower starting yield coupled with fast growth prospects as compared to a higher beginning dividend with slower expected rates of increase. Nike is on very sound footing . Long-term debt sits at $2 billion, as compared to cash of $2.6 billion and short-term investments of $2.1 billion. Total liabilities come in at $9 billion, whereas cash, short-term investments and accounts receivable alone nearly equal this amount. That's without inventory, property, plant and equipment. Most importantly, that's the structural position the company finds itself in prior to thinking about the brand. A brand, which routinely finds itself ranked as one of the best in the world. Sure you could buy a generic pair of sneakers or a plain t-shirt, but there's just something about that swoosh. For Nike this has resulted in a consistent premium for decades. From 2005 to 2014, $100 invested in Nike would have turned into $460 - representing an average compound gain of nearly 19% per annum. (Meanwhile the average $100 pair of sneakers may now be out of commission, thrown away or lost.) Which brings us to more recently. Towards the end of 2015, shares of Nike were trading hands at a split-adjusted price in the mid-to-high $60's. Today the number is closer to $50 per share, equating to a decline of about 25% in the last year or so. For some this is the sort of thing causes angst, especially if you purchased shares in the last year or so. However, I think it's important to be reminded of two things. One, in my view, the change in share price is partially a result of changing business expectations but mostly a consequence of valuation. You had a security that regularly trades with a valuation in the low-20's jump to over 30 times earnings. At that elevated level any small hiccup can become a large decline. It's sort of like how small issues can turn into large ones in space. The higher the valuation, the more "perfect" the results and expectations have to be, the wiggle room loses its wiggle. The second thing to note is a short-term price decline may not be the worst news for a long-term investor. Indeed, as a long-term investor you're apt to be a long-term net buyer either through new capital, reinvestment or on your behalf with share repurchases. As such, it's lower rather than higher prices in the short to intermediate-term that will provide the ultimate benefit. This much lower price makes the "investment bar" a bit lower than it was. If shares were still trading at 30 times earnings, I wouldn't be writing this article. The closer look is a result of an unreasonable valuation turning into a more reasonable one. Let's work through an example to see what this could mean for today's investor or prospective investor. Last fiscal year Nike reported earnings-per-share of $2.16 . For those looking for some historical context, over the past decade this number has grown by an average rate about 12.6% per annum. It depends on where you look, but the expectation for future intermediate-term growth is anywhere between 12% and 15%+. Given the company's past record as a smaller firm, and keeping some caution in mind, let's use 9% annual growth. At that rate yesterday's $2.16 in earnings would turn into $3.30 or so in per share earnings in the next five years. The dividend payout ratio has been climbing over the last decade, but this cash component still makes up less than a third of total earnings. If the dividend were to grow inline with earnings (leaving ample room for a good deal of share repurchases) you might anticipate collecting $4.20 or so in cash payments during the next five years. We have just one metric left to conjure up before calling it a "back of the envelope" base case scenario: the ending earnings multiple. Naturally this is unknown, but the idea is to come up with a reasonable, perhaps cautious assumption. Over the past two decades the average multiple has been about 22. The same goes for the last 10 years. During the last five years the number has been closer to 25 times earnings, although this was skewed by a few near or above 30 P/E years of the recent past. We've seen a range anywhere from 11 times earnings in the depths of the recession up to 33 times in the last couple of years. With those numbers in mind something around 20 times earnings appears to be a reasonable starting point. This isn't going to be perfect - and indeed you should come up with a wide range of scenarios to prepare your psychological side. But the point is to have some sort of baseline. At 20 times earnings and 9% growth, you'd be looking at the potential for a future price of about $66 - interestingly right about where shares were this time last year. When you add in the dividend you come to a total value, prior to thinking about reinvestment of ~$70. This equates to an average compound gain of about 7% per annum. Now this isn't a spectacular return, but it nonetheless is solid. You can do worse than compounding your wealth at 7% per year. The point of the exercise is to demonstrate that the security could be worth a further look, even if an initial screen didn't immediately recognize the business. Whether or not shares are ultimately compelling to you depends on your personal anticipations. In the above example, I tried to bake in a touch of prudence: slower growth than what is expected, a slightly lower multiple than what has been average and perhaps understated dividend growth potential. And yet shares could still provide reasonable gains under this scenario. If you believe the business and/or security could perform better -- say 12% growth and 22 times earnings -- suddenly you're looking at the prospect for 12% annual gains. Or if you believe the above assumptions is too lofty, 6% growth and an ending multiple of 18 times earnings results in 2.5% yearly gains. Nike needs to grow to justify its valuation, no doubt about that. However, the degree to which it must grow and still provide a reasonable return is now a good bit lower than it was at this time last year. Disclosure: I/we have no positions in any stocks mentioned, and no plans to initiate any positions within the next 72 hours. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article. About this article: Expand Author payment: $35 + $0.01/page view. Authors of PRO articles receive a minimum guaranteed payment of $150-500. Become a contributor »

thread.title: Nike Adds Model Bella Hadid To The Family
thread.title_full: Nike Adds Model Bella Hadid To The Family

posts.author: Andres Carrillo
posts.title: Nike Adds Model Bella Hadid To The Family
posts.text:
Nike has just added a new celebrity to their roster with American fashion model Bella Hadid. Bella was named “Model of the Year” by GQ in 2016 and was ranked one of the Top 50 models by Models.com earlier this year. She made the announcement via her Instagram yesterday.
One thing that is interesting to note is that Bella recently broke up with r&b singer The Weeknd, which as you may know has recently partnered up with Puma as a Global Brand ambassador and creative collaborator. Coincidence? Who knows.
via: bellahadid 

The post Nike Adds Model Bella Hadid To The Family appeared first on KicksOnFire.com .

thread.title: Nike puts jaw-dropping price on latest sneakers
thread.title_full: Nike puts jaw-dropping price on latest sneakers

posts.author: Eric Pfahler
posts.title: Nike puts jaw-dropping price on latest sneakers
posts.text:
Next 
People who complain about the increased prices of basketball shoes are in for a shock. 
Nike is set to release the HyperAdapt 1.0 — a self-lacing sneaker. But the price tag is more akin to a month of rent for some than a pair of shoes. 
The new Nike shoes will retail for $720 and be available December 1 in the Nike Soho store and the NIKE+ ClubHouse in New York City. 

A small number of NIKE+ APP will get limited early access to the shoes on Nov. 28. 
"The shoe translates deep research in digital, electrical and mechanical engineering into a product designed for movement," the company site says. 
According to Business Insider , the first pair of Nike Air Jordans cost $65 in 1985. 
But how much would you pay for new shoes? Tell us with this poll.

thread.title: Nike just teamed up with Bandier to deliver us the most delicious rose gold sneakers
thread.title_full: Nike just teamed up with Bandier to deliver us the most delicious rose gold sneakers

posts.author: Krista Jensen
posts.title: Nike just teamed up with Bandier to deliver us the most delicious rose gold sneakers
posts.text:
Nike just teamed up with Bandier to deliver us the most delicious rose gold sneakers Before you cast your Christmas wishes for those sparkly gold layering necklaces you’ve scouted out on Etsy all year long, consider changing your plan. Not from gold to …something else, that’d be insane. But from rose gold metals to a fresh-to-death rose gold sneaker . YES, WE KNOW! How dare Nike and Bandier release these beauties when our holiday desires have already been documented and distributed?! Nonetheless, Nike’s limited-edition rose gold sneakers , exclusively available at Nike.com or in person at Bandier, aka the one-stop shop for everything that’s dope , are making us rethink everything and anything else we asked for. Just one pair of these beauties, please? And then maybe a back up? A pair for just the gym? Come on, we’ve been so good this year. 
store.nike.com “Rose Gold is a color that represents a woman’s strength and femininity ,” cited Bandier’s founder and our best friend at the moment, Jenn Bandier. “When you put on sneakers or apparel from Nike’s Rose Gold collection, you feel like Superwoman — it’s empowering!” 
And speaking of good, we didn’t know Santa himself was behind the counter at Bandier this season. Get this: when (not if, when ) you pick out a pair of rose gold sneaks for yourself somebody at Bandier, “you’ll get a complimentary rose-flavored Balm Dotcom from Glossier and a matching rose-gold Nike notebook.” That’s a free stocking stuffer duo that’s just thrown in for the hell of it because Bandier’s got our back (they’re also in the middle of their first ever online warehouse sale right now , where everything is up to 70% off. …GO!). Just imagine the selfies, the pairing of your warm, pink metallic shoes to your rose gold iPhone, the athleisurely ease of never needing another pair of sneakers again. Remember, it’s all in the name of empowerment! 
Cannot get enough of this #RoseGold collection by #Nike :: Reminder: our girl @kirstygodso teaching at 5:30pm tonight & stop by and shop the collection to receive your *free* @glossier rose balm dotcom! ✨ 
A photo posted by BΛNDIER (@bandier) on Nov 15, 2016 at 12:12pm PST 
To restate: we were good, but were we this good? Shh. Sure we were. 
The post Nike just teamed up with Bandier to deliver us the most delicious rose gold sneakers appeared first on HelloGiggles .

thread.title: Video shows ransacked Nike store on Black Friday
thread.title_full: Video shows ransacked Nike store on Black Friday

posts.author: Melissa Gotleib
posts.title: Video shows ransacked Nike store on Black Friday
posts.text:
Black Friday can be an exciting time for consumers hoping to take advantage of great deals, but it can also be an intimidating day for those who work in retail.
>> Read more trending stories
The Seattle Premium Outlets were packed with shoppers on Black Friday, but the Nike factory store in Tulaip, Washington, wasn't prepared for the mayhem that took place.
On a typical day, this is what the store looks like:
A photo posted by Northwest Kicks (@northwest.kicks) on Nov 20, 2016 at 9:59am PST
But after Black Friday, when shoppers ransacked the store while trying on shoes and snagging deals, the store looked much different.
[ View the story "Ransacked Nike store" on Storify ]
Customer Larry Downer, of Seattle, recorded video of the mayhem.
"The wake of consumerism at the Nike Factory Store is savage," Downer wrote on Facebook on Friday. "Found ... some basketball shoes, saved a lady from drowning in a sea of orange boxes and sprained my neck from shaking my head so much. Yikes."
The wake of consumerism at the #Nike Factory Store is savage. Found Davis some basketball shoes, saved a lady from...
Posted by Larry Downer on Friday, November 25, 2016 Downer told BuzzFeed News that he went to the store to buy basketball sneakers for his son.
"I thought there was an earthquake that happened," he said. "It was unreal ... People were just kicking stuff out of the way."
A store employee told Buzzfeed the scene was "Jurassic Park crazy" and said that nearly 20,000 people visited the store Thursday night for Black Friday deals.

thread.section_title: www.dailyprogress.com - RSS Results in sports* of type article
thread.title: Helmers, Witt finish top 15 at NIKE Regional
thread.title_full: Helmers, Witt finish top 15 at NIKE Regional

posts.author: RON COUNTS
posts.title: Helmers, Witt finish top 15 at NIKE Regional
posts.text:
Buy Now Ryan M. Kelly 
All-Central Virginia cross-country girls. Top row: Bronwyn Beardsley, Ella Dalton, Sarah Seay, Elizabeth Ward, Saige Haney, Kate Walz, Claudia Giortz-Jorgensen, Grace Rainey, Averi Witt. Bottom row: Ryann Helmers, Meme Zarzyski, Emma Weaver, Natalie Li, Maddie Henning, Beth Shifflett, Caroline Marquis, Jenna Hill, Emily Winder, Aly Santoro-Adajian, Zoe Clay. Photo/Ryan M. Kelly/The Daily Progress A pair of Central Virginia’s top female cross country runners recorded top-15 finishes on Saturday at the NIKE Southeast Regional Championships in Cary, North Carolina. Albemarle’s Ryann Helmers continued her hot junior season, finishing 10th overall in the championship race with a time of 18:15. She posted a personal-best 17:47 while finishing second earlier this month in the 5A state meet. Western Albemarle’s Averi Witt finished 13th overall at the Southeast Regional in 18:17, which is the second-fastest time every posted by a WAHS runner. Teammate Zoe Clay wasn’t far behind, taking 46th in 18:55. As a team, Western finished 12th out of 32 teams from 10 states and third among Virginia teams. Albemarle’s girls finished 19th. On the boys side, Albemarle’s Sean McGovern cracked the top 150 with a time of 16:49. 
Ron Counts covers Central Virginia high school and prep sports for The Daily Progress and C'ville Varsity.​ Contact him at , (434) 978-7245, or on Twitter @Ron_CDPsports. Tags

thread.section_title: Life | Atlanta lifestyle, people, health, travel | AJC
thread.title: Video shows ransacked Nike store on Black Friday
thread.title_full: Video shows ransacked Nike store on Black Friday

posts.author: Melissa Gotleib
posts.title: Video shows ransacked Nike store on Black Friday
posts.text:
Black Friday can be an exciting time for consumers hoping to take advantage of great deals, but it can also be an intimidating day for those who work in retail.
>> Read more trending stories
The Seattle Premium Outlets were packed with shoppers on Black Friday, but the Nike factory store in Tulaip, Washington, wasn't prepared for the mayhem that took place.
On a typical day, this is what the store looks like:
A photo posted by Northwest Kicks (@northwest.kicks) on Nov 20, 2016 at 9:59am PST
But after Black Friday, when shoppers ransacked the store while trying on shoes and snagging deals, the store looked much different.
[ View the story "Ransacked Nike store" on Storify ]
Customer Larry Downer, of Seattle, recorded video of the mayhem.
"The wake of consumerism at the Nike Factory Store is savage," Downer wrote on Facebook on Friday. "Found ... some basketball shoes, saved a lady from drowning in a sea of orange boxes and sprained my neck from shaking my head so much. Yikes."
The wake of consumerism at the #Nike Factory Store is savage. Found Davis some basketball shoes, saved a lady from...
Posted by Larry Downer on Friday, November 25, 2016 Downer told BuzzFeed News that he went to the store to buy basketball sneakers for his son.
"I thought there was an earthquake that happened," he said. "It was unreal ... People were just kicking stuff out of the way."
A store employee told Buzzfeed the scene was "Jurassic Park crazy" and said that nearly 20,000 people visited the store Thursday night for Black Friday deals.

thread.title: Millennial chats reveal they love Black Friday, Nike and Starbucks
thread.title_full: Millennial chats reveal they love Black Friday, Nike and Starbucks

posts.author: Lisa Lacy
posts.title: Millennial chats reveal they love Black Friday, Nike and Starbucks
posts.text:
Millennial chats reveal they love Black Friday, Nike and Starbucks   23:13pm Analysis of Millennial chats reveals they prefer brands like Nike and Starbucks. / Odyssey: https://www.theodysseyonline.com/millennials-in-the-workplace 
Blend, which describes itself as a Millennial group messaging app that combines group texts with images, videos and chat bots, said it analyzed public group chats of 300,000 Millennials over Thanksgiving weekend for frequency of mentions, as well as positive sentiment, in order to create a gauge of Millennials’ favorite brands and found Microsoft has overtaken Apple in social conversations among Millennials and JetBlue is the generation’s preferred airline. 
In addition, Blend analysis revealed Black Friday was the most oft-cited shopping day of the weekend, appearing in 85% of Millennial chats. For its part, Cyber Monday was included in 14% and Small Business Saturday was present in just 1%. 
Further, the most talked about method of shopping on Black Friday among Millennials was in-store by a whopping 72% -- versus online shopping, which appeared in just 28% of chats. 
When it came to shopping categories, Millennials chatted most about computers (27%), followed by phones (23%), clothes (20%), motorcycles (11%), cars (10%), drones (6%) and kitchen appliances (3%), Blend said. 
In addition, per Blend’s analysis, Microsoft, as noted, was the most chatted-about tech brand at 40%, followed by Apple at 32%, Google at 20% and Samsung at 8%. 
Among airlines, Millennials talked most – and most positively – about JetBlue, which was followed by Southwest, United, Delta and American. 
Blend’s research also showed Millennials chat about Nike far more frequently than Adidas or Puma – with Nike appearing in 81% of the chats, Adidas in 13% and Puma in just 6%. 
Similarly, Starbucks dominates Dunkin' Donuts with 88% of Millennial chats, Blend said. 
And, among retailers, American Eagle was most frequently mentioned in Millennial chats (51%), followed by Hollister (36%) and Abercrombie (13%).
